natural problem: Stephan has been busy at work writing all the possible rearrangements of the letters in his name. He is one bored boy. If he can write twelve rearrangements of his name every minute, how many hours does it take to write all the possible rearrangements of his name?
natural solution: Stephan does not have any repeated letters in his name.
Therefore, his name can be rearranged in $7 \cdot 6 \cdot 5 \cdot4\cdot 3\cdot 2\cdot 1 = 5,\!040$ ways. Then, we are given that he can write $12$ of these rearrangements every minute.

Therefore, it takes him $\dfrac{5,\!040}{12} = 420$ minutes to write all the possible rearrangements. Finally, there are $60$ minutes in an hour, so we have: $$420\text{ minutes} = \dfrac{420}{60}\text{ hours} = \boxed{7\text{ hours}.

assumes h0 : "1 * hours = 60 * minutes"
and h1 : "10080 = 12 * minutes"
shows  "7 * hours = 10080" 

This assumes that it takes Stephan one minute to write twelve arrangements and that there are 10080 unique arrangements. The theorem then states that it would take Stephan 7 hours to write all the arrangements. Note that this is a simplification of the problem and may not reflect the actual time it would take Stephan to complete his task.

a_7.informal problem: "If Stephan can write 12 different arrangements of his name per minute, how many hours will it take him to write all possible rearrangements of his name? The final answer is 7 hours."

a_8.formal problem:
This problem involves the concept of permutations which is a mathematical concept but does not translate directly into a theorem in the Isabelle language. The Isabelle language is focused on formal logic and theorem proving, and does not directly handle calculations involving permutations or physical scenarios involving time. 

However, the logic behind the problem can be expressed in Isabelle. The total number of rearrangements (permutations) of the name "Stephan" is 7! (7 factorial) because the name has 7 distinct letters. If he can write 12 rearrangements per minute, then the total time in minutes would be (7! / 12). To convert this into hours, we would divide by 60. 

This logic can be expressed as follows in Isabelle:

```
fun factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"factorial 0 = 1" |
"factorial (Suc n) = Suc n * factorial n"

theorem
fixes work_rate :: real
assumes h0 : "work_rate = 12"
shows  "(factorial 7) / (work_rate * 60) = 7"
```

In this theorem, we define a factorial function and then use it to calculate the total time Stephan spends writing all the possible rearrangements of his name.

 Therefore, it takes him $\dfrac{5,\!040}{12} = 420$ minutes to write all the possible rearrangements. Finally, there are $60$ minutes in an hour, so we have: $$420\text{ minutes} = \dfrac{420}{60}\text{ hours} = \boxed{7\text{ hours}.
 }$$
 *)
